Description

We are all Homo sapiens (Stringer, Chris, ). By exploring our search for the earliest common ancestor with Homo neanderthalensis (Stringer, Chris, ), we can deepen our understanding of our species' family tree. While this may seem like a simplification, it clearly demonstrates our shared humanity.

Animal evolution unfolds over vast stretches of time, punctuated by occasional bursts of rapid change (Sperling, Erik A., et Richard G. Stockey, , pp. 605-622). In contrast, the evolution of language progresses swiftly (Fitch, W.T., , 3-33). This rapid linguistic evolution enables us to categorize and label groups of people and events, inadvertently fostering the perception of differences among us.

The events in the 'Review' section do not follow the pattern used in other sections and need a grammatical review.

The events can be updated or added at any time based on new research.

value.name: Enslaved people:
value.desc: Study of the slavery system across different centuries.

value.name: American Indigenous:
value.desc: Individuals who inhabited the Americas for millennia before the arrival of Europeans.

value.name: Holy Office Familiar:
value.desc: Individuals who enjoyed various privileges and constituted a sort of "third order" within the Inquisition (Saraiva, Antonio Jos√©, , pp. 240 - 243). This section lists those who applied to become Familiars and underwent thorough familial investigations before being accepted or rejected.

value.name: Muslims:
value.desc: Study of families with Muslim ancestors and their impact on human history.

value.name: People defamed as Jews:
value.desc: Individuals who lacked recent Jewish ancestry but were nonetheless labeled as Jews. The term "defamation" harks back to the era of the Inquisition and should not be applied in the same manner today.

value.name: Persecution of Jew:
value.desc: Insight into various instances of persecution throughout history.
